name.value: Synchronic and Diachronic Identity: Initial Psychometric Investigation of Multiple Instruments Designed to Assess Identity Manifestation at a Synchronic and Diachronic Level

sample.value:
We plan to collect 350 participants. 

After screening participants according to the criteria above, we expect to end up with a sample of about 300 usable participants (~85% of the original sample).

This meets various recommended criteria to the effect that factors analyses be conducted on samples of 300+, or 10 participants per item on the scale (here, > 200).

Boateng, G. O., Neilands, T. B., Frongillo, E. A., Melgar-Quiñonez, H. R., Young, S. L. (2018). Best practices for developing and validating scales for health, social, and behavioral research: A primer. Frontiers in Public Health, 6, 149. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpubh.2018.00149

The power afforded to the exploratory correlational analyses is also high. In particular, for a modest effect size of r = .3,  we would be able to detect a correlational link, at a p< .05 level of significance, and a sample size of N = 300, with a power probability of .999.

analyses.value:
As stated above, the items composing the IM—especially those on the two conventional questionnaires (CQs), and the *SI items in particular—will be evaluated in terms of their 

(a) individual discriminative power;
(b) individual coherence with the overall scale and the subscales;
(c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct or subconstruct.

These will be respectively assessed via

(a) mean extremity, standard deviation;
(b) item-(subscale) total correlations, average inter-item correlations (on a subscale);
(c) exploratory factor analysis.

The cutoff criteria employed will be conventional, and analogous to those employed in other personality and social psychology research, such as:

Jarvis, W. B. G., & Petty, R. E. (1996). The need to evaluate. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 70, 172–194. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.70.1.172

In particular, items will be marked as optimal if they

(a1) are above 1.5 and below 4.5 (on the 0 to 6 scale), 
(a2) have a standard deviation exceeding 1.5
(b1) have intended item-(subscale) total correlations exceeding r = .30 
(b2) have intended average item-item (subscale) correlations exceeding r = .20 
(b3) have UNintended item-(subscale) total correlations always <  intended item-(subscale) total correlations, preferably about half the size
(b4) have UNintended average item-item (subscale) correlations always < intended average item-item (subscale) correlations, preferably about half the size

...and following relevant item inclusion/exclusion,on the questionnaire scales...

(c1) a expected two-factor structure emerges, differentiating SI and DI items wihin each type of scale (based on scree plot visualization and/or parallel analysis)
(c2) each item exhibits an intended factor loading > beta = .30
(c3) each item exhibits an UNintended factor loadings < beta = .30, preferably half the size

In the event that a sufficient number of items do not meet all the criteria perfectly, but are In the event that a sufficient number of items do not meet all the criteria perfectly, but are borderline, those criteria may be relaxed in a minority of cases, in the interests of ensuring overall scale reliability and consistency (which will provisionally be assessed via Cronbach's Alpha and McDonald's Omega). 

In addition, the SI inventory will be analyzed separately, as well as in conjunction with the DI, given that the SI has 4 subscales, whereas the DI has no subscales.

Also assessed will be the tendency for different types of instrument, assessing the same construct (i.e., SI and DI), to correlate preferentially with another, alongside the emergence of a general positive manifold. That is, the classic multi-trait multi-matrix method may be applied here.

Exploratory analyses will mainly feature correlations between, on the one hand, various IM total scores, subscale scores, and item scores, and, on the other hand, various key indices derived from the supplementary variables listed.

outliers.value:
To help ensure its quality, we will screen our crowdsourced data as follows: 

Duplicate check: Remove all cases where the respondent is liable to have participated more than once (now done automatically by the MTurk platform, by preventing multiple responses from the same IP address).

Speed check: Remove all cases where respondents completed the study in less than 1/3 or 1/2 of the median completion time (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Completion check: Remove all cases where respondents have completed less than 90% or 95% of the key questions  (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Age check: Remove all participants reporting being under 18 years of age (despite this being a criterion specified by the platform).

Fluency check: Remove all participants reporting that their English is less than the midpoint on the 5 point scale (i.e., include only Perfect, Very Good, Okay; exclude Bad, or Very Bad).

Conscientiousness check: Remove all cases whether participants do not answer validation questions correctly (involving either or both of the following: a set of six obviously true or false questions; an instruction to write a grammatically correct but absurd short sentence).

We will inspect our data for univariate and bivariate outliers, and analyze both including and excluding them, reporting both (perhaps in a supplement).

Univariate outliers we define as those values lying outside the Tukey (1977) fence in a Box-and- Whiskers graph: below Q1 – 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR.

Bivariate outliers can be defined as lying outside the Rousseeuw, Ruts, & Tukey (2002) fence in the Bagplot, obtained by inflating B relative to the depth median T by a factor of 3.

dependent.value: The "dependent variables" here will be scores on the provisional scales and subscales described above, and each of their items, designed to capture the degree to which synchronic and diachronic identity are manifested, using philosophical quotations, visual analogues, and conventional questionnaires (CQs).

conditions.value: There will be only one "condition" here.

hypothesis.value:
People subjectively experience their own identity (i.e., their leading answers to the question “Who am I?”) on a spectrum of manifestation—from being definite, enduring, and inescapable, on the one hand (i.e., strongly manifest), to being nebulous, evanescent, and unimaginable (i.e., weakly manifest), on the other.

At a global level, degrees of identity manifestation may be defined as at a synchronic level (i.e., at one point in time) and at a diachronic level (i.e., over multiple points in time). That is, one may feel one is, or is not, a definite person, right now; and one may also feel that one is, or is not, the same person now, as one has been in the past, or will be in the future. 

Such degrees of identity manifestation are interesting to characterize in themselves. In addition, such degrees of identity manifestation are liable to have interesting psychological correlates, causes, and consequences that are worth investigating.

The present study does not so much test a hypothesis as conduct an initial psychometric evaluation, namely, of provisional versions of several self-report instruments designed to capture two dimensions of identity manifestation (IM), namely, synchronic identity (SI) and diachronic identity (DI). These instruments fall into three classes. The first class involves philosophical quotations (PQs). The second class involves visual analogues (VAs). And the third class involves conventional questionnaires (CQs). The PQs consists of quotations from philosophers David Hume and Galen Strawson, articulating the absence of SI and DI respectively, with which participants can express agreement or disagreement, using 7 response options. The VAs consist of head silhouettes—defined more or less vaguely, or containing larger or smaller interrogation marks—with which participants indicate their level of identification (SI); and of a selection of circle pairs, differing in their degree of overlap, representing respectively either the past and the present, or the present and the future—with which participants indicate their level of identification (DI). All VA items feature 7 response options. The CQs consist of a 24-item scale, designed to capture SI, and a 16-item scale, designed to capture DI, which participants can describe as being true or false, using 7 response options. In addition, whereas the DI scale is intended to be unifactorial, capturing the felt impermanence of self with all 16 items, the SI scale is intended to be multifactorial, such that the felt irreality of synchronic identity reflects felt indefiniteness, felt inscrutability, felt impressibility, and felt impersonability, each facet being captured by 6 items. Level of identity manifestation on all items will be scaled from 0 to 6.

In particular, the various identity manifestation instruments will be administered for the first time to a sizable sample of participants. From the data they provide, all the items composing them will be evaluated in terms of their (a) individual discriminative power, (b) individual coherence with their overall scale and their associated subscales, (c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct and their associated subconstructs. Also assessed will be (d) the tendency for different types of scale assessing the same construct (i.e., SI and DI) to correlate preferentially with another, alongside the emergence of a general positive manifold. On the basis of meeting, or not meeting, standard criteria in this regard, items will be retained or discarded/amended, to produce revised IM instruments.

Other studies in this line of research will do the following:

- Have revised IM items rated for the clarity and validity of their content.
- Confirm the factor structure of the revised IM instruments.
- Assess the internal consistency of the revised IM instruments.
- Assess the test-retest reliability of the revised IM instruments.
- Assess the measurement invariance of the revised IM instruments across different groups.
- Validate the revised IM instruments both convergently and discriminantly.
- Validate the revised IM instruments both concurrently and predictively.
- Assess the extent to which social desirability contributes to scores on the revised IM instruments.
- Test for the existence, strength, and direction of theoretically interesting correlates of the revised IM instruments.

In the present study, we will also, for the sake of conducting an undergraduate student project, include additional measures—all administered the provisional IM instruments.   

Some of these measures will assess the convergent and discriminant validity of the provisional IM instruments their items in a preliminary and exploratory way—with the possibility of the findings nonetheless being used diagnostically in a supplementary capacity. 

The link between the scores on IM instruments  and "dark" personality traits will be explored. So too will their link to the "Big Five" Personality traits (Extraversion, Stability, Conscientiousness, Agreebleness, and Openness). On theoretical grounds, we expect to find that lesser degrees of IM, on both SI and DI, will be positively associated with "dark" personality traits, although more so for Machiavellianism and Psychopathy than for Narcissism. In addition, we expect to find that lesser degrees of IM, of both SI and DI, will be associated with lower Agreeableness and Conscientiousness (the "darker" traits). We also we expect to find that lesser degrees of IM, of both SI and DI, will be associated with lower Stability (instability of self-concept) and greater openness (plasticity of self-concept), but higher Extraversion wil predict greater degree of IM, of both SI and DI.

"Dark" personality traits will be operationalized by whole scale and subscale scores on the  12-item Dark Triad Dirty Dozen (DTDD), which features subscales for Machiavellianism, Psychopathy, and Narcissism.

[Jonason, P, K. & Webster, G, D. (2010). The Dirty Dozen: A concise measure of the dark triad. Psychological Assessment, 22, 420-432.]

The Big Five personality traits will be operationalized by subscale scores on the 15-item version of the The Big Five Inventory-2 [BFI-2-X2], which features subscales for Extraversion, Stability, Conscientiousness, Agreebleness, and Openness.

[Soto, C. J., John, O. P. (2017a). Short and extra-short forms of the Big Five Inventory–2: The BFI-2-S and BFI-2-XS. Journal of Research in Personality, 68, 69-81.] 

In the present study, we will also collect standard demographic information on participants. In particular, this will include gender, age, national identity, and English fluency. Finally, we will ask participants for feedback on the study, and to opine what its purpose was.

hypothesis.value:
Psychopathy is a multifaceted and much debated construct. However—together with other types of so-called “dark” personalities, such as narcissism and Machiavellianism—a prominent feature of the construct is that it arguably involves several species of not caring about one or more things that are typically cared about by normal individuals—such as the future, the truth, or other people. This lack of caring—here labelled pococurantism (Italian: "little-caring")—remains under-theorized, despite the fact that it may pick out, not only a conceptually coherent and empirically tractable feature of dark personalities, but a unifying and essential feature too. In addition, pococurantism may be a construct whose correlates, causes, and effects could be profitably examined in their own right, free from the conceptual baggage and historical controversy that has dogged the conceptual conundrum that is psychopathy. Unsurprisingly, there does not yet exist any instrument designed to assess individual differences in pococurantism, either overall or in specific domains. The current research is designed to remedy this deficit, and to permit thereby theoretical and empirical progress to be made in the field of psychopathy and dark personality.

The present study does not so much test a hypothesis as conduct an initial psychometric evaluation, namely, of a provisional version of a self-report instrument designed to capture the key construct in question: the Lack of Caring Inventory (LOCI).  As its name suggests, this inventory is designed to assess, reliably and durably, individual differences in the dispositional inclination to not care about things, that is, pococurantism, whose logical opposite is "moltocurantism" (Italian: "much-caring"). In addition, pococurantism is assessed in three ontologically and psychologically distinct domains: the future (i.e., a lack of prudence); the truth (i.e., a lack of veracity); and other people (i.e., a lack of empathy). 

In its provisional form, the LOCI consists of 21-item scale, each item consisting of a pair of bipolar alternatives at opposite ends of a continuous scale, linear and horizontal. Participants move a slider from left to right to indicate their degree of relative agreement with one alternative versus the other, the slider's position always reflecting a relative preference for saving (more rightward) versus spending (more leftwards). The slider moves smoothly, and affords the respondent a 101-point resolution, scaled from +50 (most caring: "moltocurante") through 0 through -50 (least caring: "pococurante"). 

The 21-item scale is also divided into three subscales, of 7 items each, each tapping to one of the key domains in which pococurantism is expressed, namely, the future, the truth, and other people. In addition, items tapping each domain cyclically recur every three items; and different expressions, capturing a lack of caring or abundance of caring, are counterbalanced across various items, but such that none is used across adjacent items. Finally, to maximize the construct-related variability, and hence the discriminative power, of each item, phrasing is used that encourages agreement with the pococurante pole (by using adverbs reflecting candor) and discourages agreement with the moltocurante pole (by using absolutist language), given that normative pressure might be expected to do the opposite.

In particular, the inventory will be administered for the first time to a sizable sample of participants. From the data they provide, all the items composing the provisional LOCI will be evaluated in terms of their (a) individual discriminative power, (b) individual coherence with the overall scale and their associated subscales (c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct and associated their subconstructs. On the basis of meeting, or not meeting, standard criteria in this regard, items will be retained or discarded/amended, to produce a revised LOCI.

Other studies in this line of research will do the following:

- Have revised LOCI items rated for the clarity and validity of their content.
- Confirm the factor structure (one general factor, three specific factors) of the revised LOCI.
- Assess the internal consistency of the revised LOCI and its three subscales.
- Assess the test-retest reliability of the revised LOCI and its three subscales.
- Assess the measurement invariance of the revised LOCI across different groups.
- Validate the revised LOCI, and its three subscales, both convergently and discriminantly.
- Validate the revised LOCI, and its three subscales, both concurrently and predictively.
- Assess the extent to which social desirability contributes to scores on the revised LOCI, and its subscales.
- Test for the existence, strength, and direction of theoretically interesting correlates of the revised LOCI, and its subscales.

In the present study, we will also, for the sake of conducting undergraduate student projects, include additional measures—all administered after the provisional LOCI.  

Some of these measures will assess the convergent and (partly) discriminant validity of the provisional LOCI, its subscales, and its items in a preliminary and exploratory way—with the possibility of the findings nonetheless being used diagnostically in a supplementary capacity. 

First, the link between the scores on the LOCI and "dark" and "light" personality traits will be explored. On theoretical ground,s we suspect that whole scale and subscale scores on the LOCI should be positively associated with "dark" personality traits, and negatively associated with scores on "light" personality traits. For example, key indices of a psychopathic personality include self-defeating impulsivity (not caring about the future), pathological lying (not caring about the truth), and a lack of empathy (not caring about other people—all characteristics assessed by the LOCI. Conversely, non-psychopaths should be prudent, tell the truth, and be abundant in fellow-feeling.

"Dark" personality traits will be operationalized by whole scale and subscale scores on the 12-item Dark Triad Dirty Dozen (DTDD), which features subscales for Machiavellianism, Psychopathy, and Narcissism.

[Jonason, P, K. & Webster, G, D. (2010). The Dirty Dozen: A concise measure of the dark triad. Psychological Assessment, 22, 420-432.]

"Light" personality traits will be operationalized by whole scale and subscale scores on the Light Triad Scale (LTS), which features subscales for Faith in Humanity, Humanism, and Faith in Humanity.

[Kaufman, S. B.. Yaden, D. B., Hyde, E, & Tsukayama, E. (2019). The light vs. dark triad of personality: Contrasting two very different profiles of human nature. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, A467. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00467] 

Further pairs of items will directly assess, respectively, participants' temporal discounting rate (i.e., indifference towards the future); their proclivity towards lying (i.e., indifference towards veracity); and their (lack of ) dispositional agreeableness (i.e., indifference towards other people). We suspect that each of these will correlate with whole scale LOCI scores, as well as showing the theoretically expected pattern of preferential correlation with the LOCI subscales

In addition, a novel 6-item scale entitled the Priority of Promising Scale (POPS) will be included, which assesses the extent to which people morally prioritize promising-keeping. Participants read vignettes in which a promisor breaks or keeps a promise to a promisee, where the promisor and promisee are either self and another person, another person and self, or two hypothetical people. It permits both the moral prioritization of promising-keeping, and a self-serving bias the moral prioritization of promising-keeping, to be independently assessed. As making a promise involves a commitment to a course of action undertaken later (i.e., not being indifferent to the future), the performance of speech act that accords with reality (i.e., not being indifferent to the truth), and a promisee whose welfare is on the line if the promise is broken (i.e., not being indifferent to others), we suspect that pococurantism and its subscales should be inversely correlated with the moral prioritization of promising-keeping.

In the present study, we will also collect standard demographic information on participants. In particular, this will include gender, age, national identity, and English fluency. Finally, we will ask participants for feedback on the study, and to opine what its purpose was.

registration_responses.name: Pococurantism: Initial Psychometric Investigation of a Provisional 21-item Lack Of Caring Inventory (LOCI)
registration_responses.sample:
We plan to collect 350 participants. 

After screening participants according to the criteria above, we expect to end up with a sample of about 300 usable participants (~85% of the original sample).

This meets various recommended criteria to the effect that factors analyses be conducted on samples of 300+, or 10 participants per item on the scale (here, > 200).

Boateng, G. O., Neilands, T. B., Frongillo, E. A., Melgar-Quiñonez, H. R., Young, S. L. (2018). Best practices for developing and validating scales for health, social, and behavioral research: A primer. Frontiers in Public Health, 6, 149. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpubh.2018.00149

The power afforded to the exploratory correlational analyses is also high. In particular, for a modest effect size of r = .3,  we would be able to detect a correlational link, at a p< .05 level of significance, and a sample size of N = 300, with a power probability of .999.
registration_responses.analyses:
As stated above, the items composing the provisional LOCI will be evaluated in terms of their 

(a) individual discriminative power;
(b) individual coherence with the overall scale and the subscales;
(c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct or subconstruct.

These will be respectively assessed via

(a) mean extremity, standard deviation;
(b) item-total correlations, average inter-item correlation;
(c) exploratory factor analysis.

The cutoff criteria employed will be conventional, and analogous to those employed in other personality and social psychology research, such as:

Jarvis, W. B. G., & Petty, R. E. (1996). The need to evaluate. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 70, 172–194. https://doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.70.1.172

In particular, items will be marked as optimal if they

(a1) are above -25 and below +25 (on the -50 to +50 scale), 
(a2) have a standard deviation exceeding 25
(b1) have intended item-(subscale) total correlations exceeding r = .30 
(b2) have intended average item-item (subscale) correlations exceeding r = .20 
(b3) have UNintended item-(subscale) total correlations always <  intended item-(subscale) total correlations, preferably about half the size
(b4) have UNintended average item-item (subscale) correlations always < intended average item-item (subscale) correlations, preferably about half the size

...and following relevant item inclusion/exclusion...

(c1) a 3-factor structure emerges (based on scree plot visualization and/or parallel analysis)
(c2) each item exhibits an intended factor loading > beta = .30
(c3) each item exhibits an UNintended factor loadings < beta = .30, preferably half the size

In the event that a sufficient number of items do not meet all the criteria perfectly, but are borderline, those criteria may be relaxed in a minority of cases, in the interests of ensuring overall scale reliability and consistency (which will provisionally be assessed via Cronbach's Alpha and McDonald's Omega).

Exploratory analyses will mainly feature correlations between, on the one hand, various LOCI total scores, subscale scores, and item scores, and, on the other hand, various key indices derived from the supplementary variables listed.
registration_responses.outliers:
To help ensure its quality, we will screen our crowdsourced data as follows: 

Duplicate check: Remove all cases where the respondent is liable to have participated more than once (now done automatically by the MTurk platform, by preventing multiple responses from the same IP address).

Speed check: Remove all cases where respondents completed the study in less than 1/3 or 1/2 of the median completion time (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Completion check: Remove all cases where respondents have completed less than 90% or 95% of the key questions  (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Age check: Remove all participants reporting being under 18 years of age (despite this being a criterion specified by the platform).

Fluency check: Remove all participants reporting that their English is less than the midpoint on the 5 point scale (i.e., include only Perfect, Very Good, Okay; exclude Bad, or Very Bad).

Conscientiousness check: Remove all cases whether participants do not answer validation questions correctly (involving either or both of the following: a set of six obviously true or false questions; an instruction to write a grammatically correct but absurd short sentence).

We will inspect our data for univariate and bivariate outliers, and analyze both including and excluding them, reporting both (perhaps in a supplement).

Univariate outliers we define as those values lying outside the Tukey (1977) fence in a Box-and- Whiskers graph: below Q1 – 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR.

Bivariate outliers can be defined as lying outside the Rousseeuw, Ruts, & Tukey (2002) fence in the Bagplot, obtained by inflating B relative to the depth median T by a factor of 3.
registration_responses.dependent: The "dependent variables" here will be scores on the provisional SOSS, its subscales, and each of its items.
registration_responses.conditions: There will be only one "condition" here.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Psychopathy is a multifaceted and much debated construct. However—together with other types of so-called “dark” personalities, such as narcissism and Machiavellianism—a prominent feature of the construct is that it arguably involves several species of not caring about one or more things that are typically cared about by normal individuals—such as the future, the truth, or other people. This lack of caring—here labelled pococurantism (Italian: "little-caring")—remains under-theorized, despite the fact that it may pick out, not only a conceptually coherent and empirically tractable feature of dark personalities, but a unifying and essential feature too. In addition, pococurantism may be a construct whose correlates, causes, and effects could be profitably examined in their own right, free from the conceptual baggage and historical controversy that has dogged the conceptual conundrum that is psychopathy. Unsurprisingly, there does not yet exist any instrument designed to assess individual differences in pococurantism, either overall or in specific domains. The current research is designed to remedy this deficit, and to permit thereby theoretical and empirical progress to be made in the field of psychopathy and dark personality.

The present study does not so much test a hypothesis as conduct an initial psychometric evaluation, namely, of a provisional version of a self-report instrument designed to capture the key construct in question: the Lack of Caring Inventory (LOCI). In addition, pococurantism is assessed in three ontologically and psychologically distinct domains: the future (i.e., a lack of prudence); the truth (i.e., a lack of veracity); and other people (i.e., a lack of empathy). 

In its provisional form, the LOCI consists of 21-item scale, each item consisting of a pair of bipolar alternatives at opposite ends of a continuous scale, linear and horizontal. Participants move a slider from left to right to indicate their degree of relative agreement with one alternative versus the other, the slider's position always reflecting a relative preference for saving (more rightward) versus spending (more leftwards). The slider moves smoothly, and affords the respondent a 101-point resolution, scaled from +50 (most caring: "moltocurante") through 0 through -50 (least caring: "pococurante"). 

The 21-item scale is also divided into three subscales, of 7 items each, each tapping to one of the key domains in which pococurantism is expressed, namely, the future, the truth, and other people. In addition, items tapping each domain cyclically recur every three items; and different expressions, capturing a lack of caring or abundance of caring, are counterbalanced across various items, but such that none is used across adjacent items. Finally, to maximize the construct-related variability, and hence the discriminative power, of each item, phrasing is used that encourages agreement with the pococurante pole (by using adverbs reflecting candor) and discourages agreement with the moltocurante pole (by using absolutist language), given that normative pressure might be expected to do the opposite.

- Assess the extent to which social desirability contributes to scores on the revised LOCI, and its subscales.
- Test for the existence, strength, and direction of theoretically interesting correlates of the revised LOCI, and its subscales.

hypothesis.value:
The decision whether to save or spend money or resources is important. It is both economically basic and psychologically significant. Moreover, people are liable to differ reliably and durably in their preference for either saving or spending. Furthermore, these individual differences are liable to be correlates, causes, or consequences of many other important phenomena. However, there currently exists no instrument designed to assess this individual difference specifically. This is the first study in a line of research designed to remedy the deficiency.

The present study does not so much test a hypothesis as conduct an initial psychometric evaluation, namely, of a provisional version of a self-report instrument designed to capture the key construct in question: the Save Or Spend Scale (SOSS).  As its name suggests, this scale is designed to assess, reliably and durably, individual differences in the dispositional and domain-general preference for saving versus spending.

In its provisional form, the SOSS consists of 20-item scale, each item consisting of a pair of bipolar alternatives at opposite ends of a continuous scale, linear and horizontal. Participants move a slider from left to right to indicate their degree of relative agreement with one alternative versus the other, the slider's position always reflecting a relative preference for saving (more rightward) versus spending (more leftwards). The slider moves smoothly, and affords the respondent a 101-point resolution, scaled from +50 (maximal saving preference) through 0 (no preference) through -50 (maximal spending preference). Thus, higher scores indicate a relative preference for saving.

In particular, the scale will be administered for the first time to a sizable sample of participants. From the data they provide, all the items composing the provisional SOSS will be evaluated in terms of their (a) individual discriminative power, (b) individual coherence with the overall scale, and (c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct. On the basis of meeting, or not meeting, standard criteria in this regard, items will be retained or discarded/amended, to produce a revised SOSS.

Other studies in this line of research will do the following:

- Have revised SOSS items rated for the clarity and validity of their content
- Confirm the factor structure (unifactorial) of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the internal consistency of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the test-retest reliability of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the measurement invariance of the revised SOSS across different groups.
- Validate the revised SOSS both convergently and discriminantly.
- Validate the revised SOSS both concurrently and predictively.
- Assess the extent to which social desirability contributes to scores on the revised SOSS.
- Test for the existence, strength, and direction of theoretically interesting correlates of the revised SOSS .

In the present study, we will also, for the sake of an undergraduate student project, include an additional four items in the study—all administered after the provisional SOSS. These items will assess the convergent validity of the provisional SOSS and its items in a preliminary and exploratory way—with the possibility of the findings nonetheless being used diagnostically in a supplementary capacity. These items will assess, respectively, participants' temporal discounting rate (1 item); whether they are dispositionally more approach-oriented or avoidance-oriented (1 item); and whether they show behavioral signs of spending (1 item) or saving (1 item). We suspect that that scores on the SOSS scale and its items will correlate positively with a lower temporal discount rate, being more avoidance-oriented than approach-oriented, and having savings as opposed to being maxed out on a credit card.

In the present study, we will also collect standard demographic information on participants. In particular, this will include gender, age, national identity, English fluency, educational qualifications, and household net worth. Finally, we will ask participants for feedback on the study, and to opine what its purpose was.

We also suspect that scores on the SOSS scale and its items will correlate positively with greater educational qualifications and a higher household net worth, given both that people of lower socioeconomic status have less money to save, and because personal saving is liable to bolster socioeconomic status in the long-run.

Furthermore, these individual differences are liable to be correlates, causes, or consequences of many other important phenomena. However, there currently exists no instrument designed to assess this individual difference specifically. This is the first study in a line of research designed to remedy the deficiency.

The present study does not so much test a hypothesis as conduct an initial psychometric evaluation, namely, of a provisional version of a self-report instrument designed to capture the key construct in question: the Save Or Spend Scale (SOSS).  As its name suggests, this scale is designed to assess, reliably and durably, individual differences in the dispositional and domain-general preference for saving versus spending.

In its provisional form, the SOSS consists of 20-item scale, each item consisting of a pair of bipolar alternatives at opposite ends of a continuous scale, linear and horizontal. Participants move a slider from left to right to indicate their degree of relative agreement with one alternative versus the other, the slider's position always reflecting a relative preference for saving (more rightward) versus spending (more leftwards). The slider moves smoothly, and affords the respondent a 101-point resolution, scaled from +50 (maximal saving preference) through 0 (no preference) through -50 (maximal spending preference). Thus, higher scores indicate a relative preference for saving.

In particular, the scale will be administered for the first time to a sizable sample of participants. From the data they provide, all the items composing the provisional SOSS will be evaluated in terms of their (a) individual discriminative power, (b) individual coherence with the overall scale, and (c) tendency to cohere collectively into a single construct. On the basis of meeting, or not meeting, standard criteria in this regard, items will be retained or discarded/amended, to produce a revised SOSS.

Other studies in this line of research will do the following:

- Have revised SOSS items rated for the clarity and validity of their content
- Confirm the factor structure (unifactorial) of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the internal consistency of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the test-retest reliability of the revised SOSS.
- Assess the measurement invariance of the revised SOSS across different groups.
- Validate the revised SOSS both convergently and discriminantly.
- Validate the revised SOSS both concurrently and predictively.
- Assess the extent to which social desirability contributes to scores on the revised SOSS.
- Test for the existence, strength, and direction of theoretically interesting correlates of the revised SOSS .

In the present study, we will also, for the sake of an undergraduate student project, include an additional four items in the study—all administered after the provisional SOSS. These items will assess the convergent validity of the provisional SOSS and its items in a preliminary and exploratory way—with the possibility of the findings nonetheless being used diagnostically in a supplementary capacity. These items will assess, respectively, participants' temporal discounting rate (1 item); whether they are dispositionally more approach-oriented or avoidance-oriented (1 item); and whether they show behavioral signs of spending (1 item) or saving (1 item). We suspect that that scores on the SOSS scale and its items will correlate positively with a lower temporal discount rate, being more avoidance-oriented than approach-oriented, and having savings as opposed to being maxed out on a credit card.

In the present study, we will also collect standard demographic information on participants. In particular, this will include gender, age, national identity, English fluency, educational qualifications, and household net worth. Finally, we will ask participants for feedback on the study, and to opine what its purpose was.

We also suspect that scores on the SOSS scale and its items will correlate positively with greater educational qualifications and a higher household net worth, given both that people of lower socioeconomic status have less money to save, and because personal saving is liable to bolster socioeconomic status in the long-run.

name.value: Promising: Testing for the existence and moderation of a self-serving bias in the moral prioritization of promise-keeping.

other.value:
We make no prediction about whether scores on the Impersonal Index will be higher or lower on average that scores on the Self and Other indices. We suspect that they may fall in between. 

We do predict that scores on the Self, Other, and Impersonal indices will be modestly positively correlated. However, but make no prediction as regards the relative magnitude of these correlations. We suspect, however, that the First and Second Impersonal indices will be better correlated with each other, than the Self, Other, and Impersonal indices are correlated among one another. In addition, we suspect that the correlation between the Self and Other will be mediated by the Impersonal Index, the rationale being that a general commitment to promising should be the main reason why a felt obligation to other to the self, and felt obligations of the self to the other—felt obligations that might be expected to at least partly oppose one another—should correlate at all.

We also also conduct exploratory analyses with a series of demographic variables (e.g., gender, age) to see if they moderate the magnitude of the self-serving bias in the moral prioritization of promise-keeping. We make no predictions here, and suspect null effects.

In addition, the measures described here will be administered alongside a few others as part of the same data collection. The correlational links between the indices derived from both sets of measures will be examined in an exploratory way, but guided by plausible theoretical rationales, as a prelude to later more rigorous testing in a standard hypothetico-deductive way.

In particular, the data collection will featuring the first administration—to assess its psychometric merits (e.g., item discrimination, item coherence, factor structure, internal consistency)--of a candidate inventory to assess the construct of Pococurantism. This the tendency to be indifferent to, as opposed to to care about, things in general. In particular, the 21-item inventory—provisionally entitled the Lack of Caring Inventory (LOCI)—will assess this tendency as it manifests itself in respect of three very general but discrete domains: the Future; the Truth, and Other People. Furthermore, the data collection will feature the administration of three 2-item measures designed respectively to assess respondents'  temporal discounting rate, lying proneness, and dispositional disagreeableness. 

Although the POPS and the LOCI will not yet be fully validated, and although the two-items measures represent only brief operationalization of their respective constructs, it is nonetheless predicted that indices derived from the LOCI—reflective of Pococurantism—will correlate negatively with both the Impersonal Indices (reflecting the moral prioritization of promise-keeping) but positively with the Self-Serving index (reflecting the self-serving bias in the moral prioritization of promise-keeping). The rationale for the former prediction is that, for X to make promise P to Y, X must commit to a course of action undertaken later (i.e., not be indifferent to the future), X must engage in a speech act that accords with reality (i.e., not be indifferent to the truth), and X must care about the promisee Y (i.e., not be indifferent to the Other). The rationale for the latter prediction is that, when it comes to indifference, others are more liable to be recipients of it than the self. Also on the basis of these rationales, the brief indices of temporal discount rate,lying proneness, and dispositional disagreeableness are also predicted to correlate negatively with the Impersonal Indices and positively with the Self-Serving Index.

sample.value:
For the initial study, we will crowdsource 350 participants. We expect that between 250 and 300 of these participants will meet our screening criteria (71% to 85% of the original sample).

The power afforded to the within-participant t-tests is very high. In particular, for a modest effect size of d = .3,  we would be able to detect a within-group difference, at a p <  .05 level of significance, and a sample size of N = 250, with a power probability of .997. 

The power afforded to the correlational analyses is also high. In particular, for a modest effect size of r = .3,  we would be able to detect a correlational link, at a p < .05 level of significance, and a sample size of N = 250, with a power probability of .998.

analyses.value:
The first and primary hypothesis of a self-serving bias (main effect) will be tested using within-group t-tests.  In particular, scores in the Other condition will be compared against scores in the Self condition. 

The second, third, and fourth hypotheses will be tested using correlation coefficients. The Self-Serving Index, and both the First and Second Impersonal Indices, will be correlated with the whole scale and subscale scores from the DTDD (total: + narcissism, psychopathy, Machiavellianism) and the LTS (total: + faith in humanity, humanism, Kantianism).

outliers.value:
To help ensure its quality, we will screen our crowdsourced data as follows: 

Duplicate check: Remove all cases where the respondent is liable to have participated more than once (now done automatically by the MTurk platform, by preventing multiple responses from the same IP address).

Speed check: Remove all cases where respondents completed the study in less than 1/3 or 1/2 of the median completion time (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Completion check: Remove all cases where respondents have completed less than 90% or 95% of the key questions  (for short studies, the former is sometimes better).

Age check: Remove all participants reporting being under 18 years of age (despite this being a criterion specified by the platform).

Fluency check: Remove all participants reporting that their English is less than the midpoint on the 5 point scale (i.e., include only Perfect, Very Good, Okay; exclude Bad, or Very Bad).

Conscientiousness check: Remove all cases whether participants do not answer validation questions correctly (involving either or both of the following: a set of six obviously true or false questions; an instruction to write a grammatically correct but absurd short sentence).

We will inspect our data for univariate and bivariate outliers, and analyze both including and excluding them, reporting both (perhaps in a supplement).

Univariate outliers we define as those values lying outside the Tukey (1977) fence in a Box-and- Whiskers graph: below Q1 – 1.5×IQR or above Q3 + 1.5×IQR.

Bivariate outliers can be defined as lying outside the Rousseeuw, Ruts, & Tukey (2002) fence in the Bagplot, obtained by inflating B relative to the depth median T by a factor of 3.

dependent.value:
The moral prioritization of keeping one's promises to others will be operationalized as the average of the responses to the suberogatory and supererogatory items in the Self condition. (The internal consistency of the index will be captured by the Spearman-Brown adjusted correlation between the two measures.) Call this the Self Index.

The moral prioritization of others keeping their promises to oneself will be operationalized as the average of the responses to the suberogatory and supererogatory items in the Other condition. (The internal consistency of the index will be captured by the Spearman-Brown adjusted correlation between the two measures.) Call this the Other Index.

The moral prioritization of promise-keeping in general will be operationalized (in the first instance) as the average of the responses to the suberogatory and supererogatory items in the Impersonal condition. (The internal consistency of the index will be captured by the Spearman-Brown adjusted correlation between the two measures.) Call this the first Impersonal Index.

The self-serving bias in promise-keeping will be operationalized as the Other Index minus the Self Index, divided by two. Call this the Self-Serving Index.

The moral prioritization of promise-keeping in general will be operationalized (in the second) instance as the Other Index plus the Self Index, divided by two. Call this the second Impersonal Index.

"Dark" personality traits will be operationalized by whole scale and subscale scores on the Dark Triad Dirty Dozen (DTDD).

[Jonason, P, K. & Webster, G, D. (2010). The Dirty Dozen: A concise measure of the dark triad. Psychological Assessment, 22, 420-432.]

"Light" personality traits will be operationalized by whole scale and subscale scores on the Light Triad Scale (LTS).

[Kaufman, S. B.. Yaden, D. B., Hyde, E, & Tsukayama, E. (2019). The light vs. dark triad of personality: Contrasting two very different profiles of human nature. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, A467. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00467]

conditions.value:
The first and primary hypothesis of a self-serving bias (main effect) will be tested within-groups by comparing the direction, magnitude, and significance of average scores across relevant conditions, defined by sets of items on the scale that all participants complete, as described above.

The second, third, and fourth hypotheses (moderation of the self-serving bias by personality, moderation of the self-serving bias by the moral prioritization of promise-keeping, moderation of the moral prioritization of promise-keeping by personality) will be tested by evaluating the direction, magnitude, and significance of correlations between relevant variables (hence, no conditions).

hypothesis.value:
PREAMBLE

The extent to which participants regard the keeping of promises as a moral priority will be assessed using a novel 6-item scale entitled the Priority of Promising Scale (POPS). 

Each item on the scale will feature a vignette to which participants give their reaction. 

In half the vignettes, an agent will fail to keep a promise that he or she arguably should keep (suberogatory acts: failing to do a duty). In the other half, an agent will succeed in keeping a promise that they arguably need not (supererogatory acts: going beyond the call of duty). 

On suberogatory items, the question asked will be how much at fault the agent is for breaking the promise (responses on a 6-option scale: Completely, Mostly, Considerably, Somewhat, Slightly, Not at all). On supererogatory items, the question asked will be how necessary is was for the agent to keep the promise (responses on a 6-option scale: Completely, Mostly, Considerably, Somewhat, Slightly, Not at all). 

Both types of item are intended to capture of how much people morally prioritize promise-keeping.  

In addition, within each of these three-item sets, who the agent (and patient) are will vary. One item will feature the self as the promisor and another person as the promisee (Self condition); another item will feature the other person as the promisor and the self as the promisee (Other condition); and a final item will feature two hypothetical people as promisor and promisee respectively (Impersonal condition). In addition, the test will come in three versions, such that the three scenarios described in the vignettes, in each three-item set, will be counterbalanced across the three conditions. 

For the suberogatory triad, the scenarios will involve the borrowing of money, a lunch date, and an airport pick-up. For the supererogatory triad, the scenarios will involve the loan of a car, assistance at work, helping with a house move. 

Content validity will be checked by having people rate how well the items capture morally relevant promises. 

HYPOTHESES

The main hypothesis being tested that a self-serving bias exists in the moral prioritization of promise-keeping. In particular, it is hypothesized that people will regard others as under a greater moral obligation to keep promises to them, than they are to keep promises to others. The rationale for this hypothesis is that this would be consistent with a range of self-serving biases.

A secondary hypothesis being tested is that the magnitude of this self-serving bias will be moderated by personality traits. In particular, the more people exhibit "dark" personality traits (i.e., narcissism, psychopathy, Machiavellianism), and the less they exhibit "light" personality traits (faith in humanity, humanism, Kantianism), the stronger the self-serving bias will be. The rationale is that promising-keeping and promise-breaking are commonplace phenomena in everyday life, that should be partly explicable in terms of variations in people's general prosocial or antisocial dispositions. In addition, it will be investigated whether, for participants with the least "dark" and most "light" personalities, the self-serving bias will disappear or even reverse. The rationale here is that the nicest, most decent people may actually hold themselves to higher moral standards than they hold others to.

A third hypothesis being tested is that the moral prioritization of promise-keeping, above and beyond the self-serving bias, will be inversely correlated with the magnitude of that self-serving bias. The rationale is that, to the extent to which promise-keeping is a regarded as a moral priority, it will be regarded as equally and objectively binding on everyone.

A fourth hypothesis being tested is that the moral prioritization of promise-keeping, above and beyond the self-serving bias, will be inversely correlated with "dark" personality traits (i.e., narcissism, psychopathy, Machiavellianism), and positive correlated with "light" personality traits (Faith in Humanity, Humanism, Kantianism). The rationale can be derived from a combination of those for the second and third hypotheses above.

attributes.title: The interplay between dopamine genes and diet
attributes.description: The neurotransmitter dopamine plays a central role in several cognitive domains such as motivation, reward-processing, reinforcement learning, decision-making and executive functions including working memory and attention (Arnsten, Wang, & Paspalas, 2012; Logue & Gould, 2013; Rogers, 2011; Schultz, 2002; Volkow, Wise, & Baler, 2017). Results of our recent studies point towards prominent alterations in these domains in overweight and obesity and suggest the existence of a non-linear relationship between markers of obesity and central dopamine tone (Horstmann, Fenske, & Hankir, 2015). Dopamine tone in the brain depends on both genetic and environmental factors. Genetic differences in important genes within the dopaminergic synapse, i.e. COMT (important for dopamine degradation) and dopamine receptor D2 (A1 allele of Taq1A), lead to altered dopamine signaling and can therefore contribute to higher vulnerability for diet-induced obesity (Annerbrink et al., 2008; Epstein et al., 2007). One important environmental factor that is hypothesized to affect dopamine transmission in obesity is an unhealthy diet. Accumulating evidence from animal research suggests that observed differences in dopamine signaling in obesity may be induced by diet rather than obesity (Geiger et al., 2009; Narayanaswami, Thompson, Cassis, Bardo, & Dwoskin, 2013; van de Giessen et al., 2013; Vucetic, Carlin, Totoki, & Reyes, 2012). However, the evidence for diet-induced alterations in dopamine signal transmission and their effects on dopamine-mediated cognitive processes in humans is scarce. In the proposed study, we aim to address the effect of diet high in fat and sugar on dopamine signal transmission in the brain and on dopamine-mediated cognitive performance.

summary.value:
A NEUROCOGNITIVE INVESTIGATION OF THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN DIET, DOPAMINE AND COGNITIVE PERFORMANCE [UPDATE]

This preregistration gives an overview of the background, general research questions, design, and outcome measures of a larger study that will be analyzed in separate parts addressing distinct research questions. Detailed information about the specific research questions of the subprojects and their respective analysis plans can be found in separate preregistrations.

Note that this preregistration is an update of the public registration https://osf.io/8pxgd. We have added more specific research questions regarding the entire study population and added the respective analysis plans.

At the time of submission of this updated preregistration, data acquisition has finished. 88 full datasets have been collected. The data have not been analyzed before preregistration and were only accessed for sanity checks that did not address any of the research questions.



1. SUMMARY
The neurotransmitter dopamine plays a central role in several cognitive domains such as motivation, reward-processing, reinforcement learning, decision-making and executive functions including working memory and attention (Arnsten, Wang, & Paspalas, 2012; Logue & Gould, 2013; Rogers, 2011; Schultz, 2002; Volkow, Wise, & Baler, 2017). Results of our recent studies point towards prominent alterations in these domains in overweight and obesity and suggest the existence of a non-linear relationship between markers of obesity and central dopamine tone (Horstmann, Fenske, & Hankir, 2015). Dopamine tone in the brain depends on both genetic and environmental factors. Via epigenetic mechanisms, environmental factors may directly modify the transcription of genes involved in dopamine metabolism and signaling. Genetic differences in genes that play an important role within the dopaminergic synapse, i.e. COMT (important for dopamine degradation) and dopamine receptor D2 (A1 allele of Taq1A), lead to altered dopamine signaling and can therefore contribute to higher vulnerability for diet-induced obesity (Annerbrink et al., 2008; Epstein et al., 2007). One important environmental factor that is hypothesized to affect dopamine transmission in obesity is an unhealthy diet. Accumulating evidence from animal research suggests that observed differences in dopamine signaling in obesity may be induced by diet rather than obesity (Geiger et al., 2009; Narayanaswami, Thompson, Cassis, Bardo, & Dwoskin, 2013; van de Giessen et al., 2013; Vucetic, Carlin, Totoki, & Reyes, 2012). However, the evidence for diet-induced alterations in dopamine signal transmission and their effects on dopamine-mediated cognitive processes in humans is scarce. In a first study, we now report initial indirect evidence for diet-related differences in central dopamine availability (Hartmann et al., 2019). We observed higher peripheral levels of dopamine precursors (i.e., the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine) relative to other large neutral amino acids in those volunteers who reported high intake of saturated fat and added sugar compared to those reporting low intake. The ratio of dopamine precursors to other large neutral amino acids has been shown to reflect central dopamine availability in the human striatum (Montgomery et al., 2003; Leyton et al., 2004). In the proposed study, we aim to address the relationship between a diet high in fat and sugar and proxies of systemic dopamine signal transmission in the brain and on dopamine-mediated cognitive performance. Further, we aim to replicate the diet-related group difference in peripheral dopamine precursor availability in an independent sample.

2. RESEARCH QUESTIONS 
2.1 GENERAL RESEARCH QUESTIONS (see separate preregistrations for analysis plan)
•	Is the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed habitually associated with dopamine-mediated cognition? 
•	Does (epi)genetic variation explain variance in the association between diet and dopamine-mediated cognition? 

2.2 RESEARCH QUESTIONS RELATED TO THE STUDY POPULATION (see below for analysis plan)
•	Is the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed associated with peripheral availability of dopamine precursors? Based on previous findings in our lab (Hartmann et al., 2019) we predict that on the group level participants who follow a diet high in saturated fat and added sugar have a higher peripheral availability of peripheral dopamine precursors (pDAP)
•	Is genetic predisposition in genes related to dopamine transmission associated with the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed (high vs low)?
•	Are our putative proxies of dopamine (eye blink rate, working memory capacity, dopaminergic genes mRNA expression) associated with diet-related group differences in peripheral availability of dopamine precursors?

3. METHODS

3.1 PARTICIPANTS
Data acquisition will end on 31st of January 2020 due to resource limitations. We will not be able to reach the desired sample size of 140 participants, 70 participants per dietary group, but intend to end up with groups of similar size (currently 43 vs 43). All volunteers complete the Dietary Fat and free Sugar – Short Questionnaire (DFS) assessing self-reported dietary style regarding fat and sugar intake. Cut-off values for the diet groups were defined based on data reported in Fromm & Horstmann, 2019:
•	High Fat and Sugar (HFS) group: DFS score ≥ 62 (highest quartile)
•	Low Fat and Sugar (LFS) group: DFS score ≤ 52 (lowest quartile). The original cutoff was 48, but had to be adjusted to 52 one year into testing due to substantial problems in recruiting LFS participants

Inclusion criteria: 
•	Male, healthy participants between the age of 18 and 40 years 
•	right-handed 
•	fluent German speakers
•	DFS-Q score ≥ 62 (HFS) or ≤ 52 (LFS) 

Exclusion criteria 
•	BMI below 18.5 or above 45 kg/m²
•	personal or first-degree-relative history of psychiatric or neurological disease
•	history of significant head injury (i.e. loss of consciousness)
•	contraindications for MRI 
•	metabolic diseases, i.e. diabetes mellitus type I/II or thyroid dysfunction
•	regular intake of psychotropic medications, illicit drug use, excessive alcohol use (on average no more than 20g alcohol/day ≙ 1-2 beer 0,5 l/day), smoking (no regular smoking within the last year, no cigarettes within the last 3 months)
•	excessive self-reported physical exercise, because of its effect on striatal dopamine (Petzinger et al., 2015)
•	BDI score above 19 (Beck Depression Inventory, Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) to control for depressive symptoms
•	mean EDE-Q above 3.88 (Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (Hilbert, Zwaan, & Braehler, 2012)) indicating possible presence of an eating disorder

3.2 MEASUREMENTS
BEHAVIORAL TESTS OF DOPAMINE-MEDIATED COGNITION
•	“Two step task” (adapted Daw, Gershman, Seymour, Dayan, & Dolan, 2011; Deserno et al., 2015): a sequential decision-making task that assesses the degree of model-based and model-free control in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Horizon task” (adapted from Wilson, Geana, White, Ludvig, & Cohen, 2014): assesses the distinction of goal-directed vs. random exploratory behavior in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Working memory task” (Fallon & Cools, 2014): a delayed match-to-sample task that assesses stability and flexibility of working memory representations
•	“Reversal learning task” (adapted from Reiter, Heinze, Schlagenhauf, & Deserno, 2017): a probabilistic reversal learning task to assess behavioral flexibility in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Pavlovian bias task” (Swart et al., 2017): assesses the impact of reward and punishment on instrumental learning from Pavlovian response biasing

3.3 BLOOD MEASURES
Peripheral dopamine markers
Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNP) as genetic markers of dopamine transmission
•	Post hoc grouping based on Catechol-O-Methyltransferase (rs4680)(Dickinson & Elvevåg, 2009) 
•	Post hoc grouping based on DRD2/ANKK1 Taq1A (rs1800497) polymorphisms (Pohjalainen et al., 1998)
•	Exploratory analyses of DRD2 C957T variant (rs6277), alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase FTO (rs8053740 and rs8050136), dopamine- and cAMP-regulated neuronal phosphoprotein DARPP-32 (rs907094), and dopamine active transporter (DAT) variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism
mRNA expression and methylation patterns in relation to diet
•	dopamine pathway: rate limiting enzyme of dopamine synthesis tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), dopamine receptors D2 and D5, DARPP-32, COMT, dopamine active transporter (DAT) 
•	thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue: uncoupling proteins UCP2 and UCP3
Estimation of central dopamine availability after Coull, Hwang, Leyton, & Dagher, 2012
•	Amino acid profile of dopamine precursor tyrosine and phenylalanine, and transporter competitors leucine, isoleucine, methionine, tryptophan and valine
Factors to characterize the groups
•	Metabolic markers: glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), glucose, C-peptide, triglycerides, cholesterol
•	Metabolic hormones: insulin, leptin, total ghrelin
•	Organic health marker: alanine transaminase (ALAT), aspartate transaminase (ASAT), gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT), creatinine, albumin, thyrotropic hormone (TSH)
•	Systemic inflammatory marker: high-sensitive C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha)

3.4 SELF-REPORT QUESTIONNAIRES
3.4.1 Characterizing groups in terms of eating behavior 
•	Dietary Fat and free Sugar – Short Questionnaire (DFS; Francis & Stevenson, 2013, German version: Fromm & Horstmann, 2019) assesses intake of 26 dietary items high in fat and/or sugar (for grouping of participants)
•	Food Frequency Questionnaire (DEGS; Haftenberger et al., 2010) to assess frequency of food intake and portion size
•	Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (FEV; Schober, 1991) to assess eating behavior according to three subscales (cognitive control of eating/restrained eating, emotional or situational perturbance of eating behavior, sensation of hunger)
•	Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS; Meule, Vögele, & Kübler, 2012) 
•	Food Craving Questionnaire-Trait (FCQ-T; Meule, Hermann, & Kübler, 2014) to assess food craving as a trait

3.4.2 Characterizing groups in terms of personality traits
•	NEO-Five Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI; Saklofske, Boyle, & Matthews, 2008) to assess five fundamental personality traits (openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness and neuroticism)
•	Behavioural approach and avoidance system questionnaire (BIS/BAS; Strobel, Beauducel, Debener, & Brocke, 2001) to assess individual differences in the behavioral inhibition system (BIS) and behavioral approach system (BAS), the latter including subscales for fun seeking, drive and reward responsiveness
•	Barrat Impulsiveness Scale (BIS 15; Hartmann, Rief, & Hilbert, 2011) to assess individual differences in impulsivity 
•	Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking (UPPS) Impulsive Behavior Scale (Schmidt, Gay, d’Acremont, & van der Linden, 2008) to assess four specific aspects of impulsive behavior: urgency (tendency to act rashly under negative emotions), lack of premeditation (tendency to act without overthinking the consequences), lack of perseverance (inability to stay focused on a task), sensation seeking (tendency to seek for novel and exciting experiences)

3.4.3 Characterizing groups in terms of physical activity
•	International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ; Hagströmer, Oja, & Sjöström, 2006) to assess individual differences in physical activity by categorizing individuals in terms of low, moderate, and high physical activity

3.5 SEVEN-DAY PEDOMETER MEASUREMENT
Alterations in dopaminergic transmission seem to exert an influence on physical activity (Friend et al., 2017; Kravitz et al., 2016). Participants in this study will wear a pedometer to measure step count as estimate for physical activity for seven consecutive days after completion of the last test day. Physical activity is an additional outcome measure and will be compared between groups. 

3.6 NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
•	“Reitan trail making tests part A and B” (Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Test Battery, REITAN, 1955) for assessing visual-motor ability, processing speed, and mental flexibility
•	“Digit Symbol Substitution Test” (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Wechsler 1955) for assessing attention and associative abilities
•	“Digit span test” (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Wechsler 1955) for assessing working memory capacity
•	“Wiener-Matrizen-Test 2” (Formann, Waldherr & Piswanger, 1979) to control for general intelligence. 

3.7 EYE-BLINK-RATE 
Eye blink rate will be measured for a duration of 5 minutes as a putative proxy for dopamine tone in the central nervous system (Jongkees & Colzato, 2016) (but see also Dang et al., 2017; Sescousse et al., 2018).

4. ANALYSES PLAN RELATED TO THE STUDY POPULATION
4.1 CENTRAL DOPAMINE PRECURSOR AVAILABILITY
The ratio of peripheral dopamine precursors Phenylalanine and Tyrosine to other large neutral amino acids – Leucine (Leu), Isoleucine (Ile), Lysine (Lys), Methionine (Met), Valine (Val), Threonine (Thr), Tryptophan (Trp) – has been shown to reflect central dopamine synthesis (Fernstrom, 2013). Similar to Hartmann et al., 2019 we calculate central dopamine precursor availability (pDAP) as 
pDAP = Phe + Tyr/(Leu + Ile + Lys + Met + Val + Thr + Trp)
for each group. We will compare pDAP between the two groups using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s t-test).

4.2 DISTRIBUTION OF GENOTYPES OVER DIET GROUPS
To test whether genotypic variation in genes related to dopamine transmission predicts consumption of saturated fat and added sugar we use Pearson’s chi-squared test with diet groups (LFS vs HFS) and  SNP variants for each gene separately as categories. SNP variants of each gene will be grouped as follows:
•	Taq1A: Taq1 risk allele carriers vs non-carriers
•	COMT: Val/Val vs Val/Met vs Met/Met
•	C957T: C/C vs C/T vs T/T
•	DARPP-32: G/G vs G/A vs A/A. In case the number of participants in the G/G is low (< 5), we combine G/G and G/A carriers (see Frank et al., 2007)
•	FTO (rs8053740):
•	FTO (rs8050136): A/A vs A/C vs C/C. In case the number of participants in the A/A is low (< 5), we combine A/A and A/C carriers (see Sevgi et al., 2015)
 
4.3 GROUP DIFFERENCES IN PUTATIVE PROXIES OF CENTRAL DOPAMINE
•	Mean eye blink rate per minute
•	Maximum backward digit span
•	mRNA expression levels of dopaminergic genes
Group differences in the three abovementioned measures will be tested using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s t-test). The relationship of these dopamine proxies with pDAP will be tested using Pearson correlation coefficient, or Spearman rank correlation coefficient in case the data is not normally distributed and heteroscedasticity is detected. Linear models with pDAP as independent and each of the three putative dopamine proxies as dependent variable will test the association of those measurements

4.4 GROUP DIFFERENCES IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY
Group differences in physical activity will be tested using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s test). Physical activity will be defined as daily average step count (total steps/number measurement days).
