registration_responses.summary:
A NEUROCOGNITIVE INVESTIGATION OF THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN DIET, DOPAMINE AND COGNITIVE PERFORMANCE [UPDATE]

This preregistration gives an overview of the background, general research questions, design, and outcome measures of a larger study that will be analyzed in separate parts addressing distinct research questions. Detailed information about the specific research questions of the subprojects and their respective analysis plans can be found in separate preregistrations.

Note that this preregistration is an update of the public registration https://osf.io/8pxgd. We have added more specific research questions regarding the entire study population and added the respective analysis plans.

At the time of submission of this updated preregistration, data acquisition has finished. 88 full datasets have been collected. The data have not been analyzed before preregistration and were only accessed for sanity checks that did not address any of the research questions.



1. SUMMARY
The neurotransmitter dopamine plays a central role in several cognitive domains such as motivation, reward-processing, reinforcement learning, decision-making and executive functions including working memory and attention (Arnsten, Wang, & Paspalas, 2012; Logue & Gould, 2013; Rogers, 2011; Schultz, 2002; Volkow, Wise, & Baler, 2017). Results of our recent studies point towards prominent alterations in these domains in overweight and obesity and suggest the existence of a non-linear relationship between markers of obesity and central dopamine tone (Horstmann, Fenske, & Hankir, 2015). Dopamine tone in the brain depends on both genetic and environmental factors. Via epigenetic mechanisms, environmental factors may directly modify the transcription of genes involved in dopamine metabolism and signaling. Genetic differences in genes that play an important role within the dopaminergic synapse, i.e. COMT (important for dopamine degradation) and dopamine receptor D2 (A1 allele of Taq1A), lead to altered dopamine signaling and can therefore contribute to higher vulnerability for diet-induced obesity (Annerbrink et al., 2008; Epstein et al., 2007). One important environmental factor that is hypothesized to affect dopamine transmission in obesity is an unhealthy diet. Accumulating evidence from animal research suggests that observed differences in dopamine signaling in obesity may be induced by diet rather than obesity (Geiger et al., 2009; Narayanaswami, Thompson, Cassis, Bardo, & Dwoskin, 2013; van de Giessen et al., 2013; Vucetic, Carlin, Totoki, & Reyes, 2012). However, the evidence for diet-induced alterations in dopamine signal transmission and their effects on dopamine-mediated cognitive processes in humans is scarce. In a first study, we now report initial indirect evidence for diet-related differences in central dopamine availability (Hartmann et al., 2019). We observed higher peripheral levels of dopamine precursors (i.e., the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine) relative to other large neutral amino acids in those volunteers who reported high intake of saturated fat and added sugar compared to those reporting low intake. The ratio of dopamine precursors to other large neutral amino acids has been shown to reflect central dopamine availability in the human striatum (Montgomery et al., 2003; Leyton et al., 2004). In the proposed study, we aim to address the relationship between a diet high in fat and sugar and proxies of systemic dopamine signal transmission in the brain and on dopamine-mediated cognitive performance. Further, we aim to replicate the diet-related group difference in peripheral dopamine precursor availability in an independent sample.

2. RESEARCH QUESTIONS 
2.1 GENERAL RESEARCH QUESTIONS (see separate preregistrations for analysis plan)
•	Is the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed habitually associated with dopamine-mediated cognition? 
•	Does (epi)genetic variation explain variance in the association between diet and dopamine-mediated cognition? 

2.2 RESEARCH QUESTIONS RELATED TO THE STUDY POPULATION (see below for analysis plan)
•	Is the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed associated with peripheral availability of dopamine precursors? Based on previous findings in our lab (Hartmann et al., 2019) we predict that on the group level participants who follow a diet high in saturated fat and added sugar have a higher peripheral availability of peripheral dopamine precursors (pDAP)
•	Is genetic predisposition in genes related to dopamine transmission associated with the amount of saturated fat and added sugar consumed (high vs low)?
•	Are our putative proxies of dopamine (eye blink rate, working memory capacity, dopaminergic genes mRNA expression) associated with diet-related group differences in peripheral availability of dopamine precursors?

3. METHODS

3.1 PARTICIPANTS
Data acquisition will end on 31st of January 2020 due to resource limitations. We will not be able to reach the desired sample size of 140 participants, 70 participants per dietary group, but intend to end up with groups of similar size (currently 43 vs 43). All volunteers complete the Dietary Fat and free Sugar – Short Questionnaire (DFS) assessing self-reported dietary style regarding fat and sugar intake. Cut-off values for the diet groups were defined based on data reported in Fromm & Horstmann, 2019:
•	High Fat and Sugar (HFS) group: DFS score ≥ 62 (highest quartile)
•	Low Fat and Sugar (LFS) group: DFS score ≤ 52 (lowest quartile). The original cutoff was 48, but had to be adjusted to 52 one year into testing due to substantial problems in recruiting LFS participants

Inclusion criteria: 
•	Male, healthy participants between the age of 18 and 40 years 
•	right-handed 
•	fluent German speakers
•	DFS-Q score ≥ 62 (HFS) or ≤ 52 (LFS) 

Exclusion criteria 
•	BMI below 18.5 or above 45 kg/m²
•	personal or first-degree-relative history of psychiatric or neurological disease
•	history of significant head injury (i.e. loss of consciousness)
•	contraindications for MRI 
•	metabolic diseases, i.e. diabetes mellitus type I/II or thyroid dysfunction
•	regular intake of psychotropic medications, illicit drug use, excessive alcohol use (on average no more than 20g alcohol/day ≙ 1-2 beer 0,5 l/day), smoking (no regular smoking within the last year, no cigarettes within the last 3 months)
•	excessive self-reported physical exercise, because of its effect on striatal dopamine (Petzinger et al., 2015)
•	BDI score above 19 (Beck Depression Inventory, Beck, Steer, & Brown, 1996) to control for depressive symptoms
•	mean EDE-Q above 3.88 (Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (Hilbert, Zwaan, & Braehler, 2012)) indicating possible presence of an eating disorder

3.2 MEASUREMENTS
BEHAVIORAL TESTS OF DOPAMINE-MEDIATED COGNITION
•	“Two step task” (adapted Daw, Gershman, Seymour, Dayan, & Dolan, 2011; Deserno et al., 2015): a sequential decision-making task that assesses the degree of model-based and model-free control in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Horizon task” (adapted from Wilson, Geana, White, Ludvig, & Cohen, 2014): assesses the distinction of goal-directed vs. random exploratory behavior in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Working memory task” (Fallon & Cools, 2014): a delayed match-to-sample task that assesses stability and flexibility of working memory representations
•	“Reversal learning task” (adapted from Reiter, Heinze, Schlagenhauf, & Deserno, 2017): a probabilistic reversal learning task to assess behavioral flexibility in the reward and punishment domain
•	“Pavlovian bias task” (Swart et al., 2017): assesses the impact of reward and punishment on instrumental learning from Pavlovian response biasing

3.3 BLOOD MEASURES
Peripheral dopamine markers
Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNP) as genetic markers of dopamine transmission
•	Post hoc grouping based on Catechol-O-Methyltransferase (rs4680)(Dickinson & Elvevåg, 2009) 
•	Post hoc grouping based on DRD2/ANKK1 Taq1A (rs1800497) polymorphisms (Pohjalainen et al., 1998)
•	Exploratory analyses of DRD2 C957T variant (rs6277), alpha-ketoglutarate-dependent dioxygenase FTO (rs8053740 and rs8050136), dopamine- and cAMP-regulated neuronal phosphoprotein DARPP-32 (rs907094), and dopamine active transporter (DAT) variable number of tandem repeats (VNTR) polymorphism
mRNA expression and methylation patterns in relation to diet
•	dopamine pathway: rate limiting enzyme of dopamine synthesis tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), dopamine receptors D2 and D5, DARPP-32, COMT, dopamine active transporter (DAT) 
•	thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue: uncoupling proteins UCP2 and UCP3
Estimation of central dopamine availability after Coull, Hwang, Leyton, & Dagher, 2012
•	Amino acid profile of dopamine precursor tyrosine and phenylalanine, and transporter competitors leucine, isoleucine, methionine, tryptophan and valine
Factors to characterize the groups
•	Metabolic markers: glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), glucose, C-peptide, triglycerides, cholesterol
•	Metabolic hormones: insulin, leptin, total ghrelin
•	Organic health marker: alanine transaminase (ALAT), aspartate transaminase (ASAT), gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT), creatinine, albumin, thyrotropic hormone (TSH)
•	Systemic inflammatory marker: high-sensitive C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha)

3.4 SELF-REPORT QUESTIONNAIRES
3.4.1 Characterizing groups in terms of eating behavior 
•	Dietary Fat and free Sugar – Short Questionnaire (DFS; Francis & Stevenson, 2013, German version: Fromm & Horstmann, 2019) assesses intake of 26 dietary items high in fat and/or sugar (for grouping of participants)
•	Food Frequency Questionnaire (DEGS; Haftenberger et al., 2010) to assess frequency of food intake and portion size
•	Three-Factor Eating Questionnaire (FEV; Schober, 1991) to assess eating behavior according to three subscales (cognitive control of eating/restrained eating, emotional or situational perturbance of eating behavior, sensation of hunger)
•	Yale Food Addiction Scale (YFAS; Meule, Vögele, & Kübler, 2012) 
•	Food Craving Questionnaire-Trait (FCQ-T; Meule, Hermann, & Kübler, 2014) to assess food craving as a trait

3.4.2 Characterizing groups in terms of personality traits
•	NEO-Five Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI; Saklofske, Boyle, & Matthews, 2008) to assess five fundamental personality traits (openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness and neuroticism)
•	Behavioural approach and avoidance system questionnaire (BIS/BAS; Strobel, Beauducel, Debener, & Brocke, 2001) to assess individual differences in the behavioral inhibition system (BIS) and behavioral approach system (BAS), the latter including subscales for fun seeking, drive and reward responsiveness
•	Barrat Impulsiveness Scale (BIS 15; Hartmann, Rief, & Hilbert, 2011) to assess individual differences in impulsivity 
•	Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance, Sensation Seeking (UPPS) Impulsive Behavior Scale (Schmidt, Gay, d’Acremont, & van der Linden, 2008) to assess four specific aspects of impulsive behavior: urgency (tendency to act rashly under negative emotions), lack of premeditation (tendency to act without overthinking the consequences), lack of perseverance (inability to stay focused on a task), sensation seeking (tendency to seek for novel and exciting experiences)

3.4.3 Characterizing groups in terms of physical activity
•	International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ; Hagströmer, Oja, & Sjöström, 2006) to assess individual differences in physical activity by categorizing individuals in terms of low, moderate, and high physical activity

3.5 SEVEN-DAY PEDOMETER MEASUREMENT
Alterations in dopaminergic transmission seem to exert an influence on physical activity (Friend et al., 2017; Kravitz et al., 2016). Participants in this study will wear a pedometer to measure step count as estimate for physical activity for seven consecutive days after completion of the last test day. Physical activity is an additional outcome measure and will be compared between groups. 

3.6 NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL TESTS
•	“Reitan trail making tests part A and B” (Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Test Battery, REITAN, 1955) for assessing visual-motor ability, processing speed, and mental flexibility
•	“Digit Symbol Substitution Test” (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Wechsler 1955) for assessing attention and associative abilities
•	“Digit span test” (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Wechsler 1955) for assessing working memory capacity
•	“Wiener-Matrizen-Test 2” (Formann, Waldherr & Piswanger, 1979) to control for general intelligence. 

3.7 EYE-BLINK-RATE 
Eye blink rate will be measured for a duration of 5 minutes as a putative proxy for dopamine tone in the central nervous system (Jongkees & Colzato, 2016) (but see also Dang et al., 2017; Sescousse et al., 2018).

4. ANALYSES PLAN RELATED TO THE STUDY POPULATION
4.1 CENTRAL DOPAMINE PRECURSOR AVAILABILITY
The ratio of peripheral dopamine precursors Phenylalanine and Tyrosine to other large neutral amino acids – Leucine (Leu), Isoleucine (Ile), Lysine (Lys), Methionine (Met), Valine (Val), Threonine (Thr), Tryptophan (Trp) – has been shown to reflect central dopamine synthesis (Fernstrom, 2013). Similar to Hartmann et al., 2019 we calculate central dopamine precursor availability (pDAP) as 
pDAP = Phe + Tyr/(Leu + Ile + Lys + Met + Val + Thr + Trp)
for each group. We will compare pDAP between the two groups using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s t-test).

4.2 DISTRIBUTION OF GENOTYPES OVER DIET GROUPS
To test whether genotypic variation in genes related to dopamine transmission predicts consumption of saturated fat and added sugar we use Pearson’s chi-squared test with diet groups (LFS vs HFS) and  SNP variants for each gene separately as categories. SNP variants of each gene will be grouped as follows:
•	Taq1A: Taq1 risk allele carriers vs non-carriers
•	COMT: Val/Val vs Val/Met vs Met/Met
•	C957T: C/C vs C/T vs T/T
•	DARPP-32: G/G vs G/A vs A/A. In case the number of participants in the G/G is low (< 5), we combine G/G and G/A carriers (see Frank et al., 2007)
•	FTO (rs8053740):
•	FTO (rs8050136): A/A vs A/C vs C/C. In case the number of participants in the A/A is low (< 5), we combine A/A and A/C carriers (see Sevgi et al., 2015)
 
4.3 GROUP DIFFERENCES IN PUTATIVE PROXIES OF CENTRAL DOPAMINE
•	Mean eye blink rate per minute
•	Maximum backward digit span
•	mRNA expression levels of dopaminergic genes
Group differences in the three abovementioned measures will be tested using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s t-test). The relationship of these dopamine proxies with pDAP will be tested using Pearson correlation coefficient, or Spearman rank correlation coefficient in case the data is not normally distributed and heteroscedasticity is detected. Linear models with pDAP as independent and each of the three putative dopamine proxies as dependent variable will test the association of those measurements

4.4 GROUP DIFFERENCES IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY
Group differences in physical activity will be tested using the independent samples unequal variances t-test (Welch’s test). Physical activity will be defined as daily average step count (total steps/number measurement days).

attributes.title: Team in Life, Team in Stress - Jealousy in romantic couples and its influence on self-esteem

q1.value: Team in Life, Team in Stress - Jealousy in romantic couples and its influence on self-esteem

q2.value: Sophia Weimann, Beatrice Stocker, Hannah Weber, Annika Schneider

q3.value: Our purpose is to find out if there is an effect of jealousy in romantic couples on self-esteem. We induce jealousy by asking the participants to remember or imagine a situation of jealousy or ostracism with their current romantic partner. They should describe this situation as accurately as possible and write it down. Via pre and post questionnaires outcomes we compare differences in self-esteem. It is an online-study on Unipark.

q4.value:
1. In the condition "situation with jealousy" self-esteem decreases more than in the control condition "last positive experience together". 
2. In the condition "situation with ostracism" self esteem decreases more than in the control condition "last positive experience together".
3. In the condition "situation with jealousy" self esteem decreases more than in the condition "discussed/solved jealousy".

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: It is a mixed-design analysis of variance (ANOVA) with repeated measures. Between-subject variable are four conditions for the description of situation, in which each person is randomly assigned to. Within-subject variable are pre and post measures of self-esteem, before and after they remembered or imagined a situation in their condition. Dependent variable are the outcomes about explicit self-esteem by giving participants a questionnaire. Our goal is to see if self-esteem decreases in conditions of jealousy and envy more than in others.

q9.value: Unipark will do block randomisation, where each participant will be automatically, randomly assigned to one of the four equally sized, predetermined blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through all experimenters, who are 15 psychology students. All the participants have the chance to win movie vouchers for two people. Psychology students get half of a participation hour for their participation. Participants must be at least 18 years old and they have to be at least 6 months in a romantic relationship. There are just mixed-gender relationships included in this study.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 48 participants.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We have a categorial variable with four conditions, to which participants are randomly assigned to. First condition is called "situation with jealousy". In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, where they experienced jealousy in their romantic relationship. Second condition is called "discussed/solved jealousy". In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, where they discussed or solved feelings of jealousy with their romantic partner. Third condition is "situation with ostracism". In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, where they experienced ostracism in their romantic relationship. Fourth condition is called "last positive experience together". In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, when they last experienced a positive event together. 
Participants should always describe as accurately as possible the situation, where they  experienced the specific feeling/event in their current romantic relationship. If participants did not experience the feeling/event, they should imagine a situation in their current romantic relationship, where they think it is possible to experience this feeling/event.

We measure self-esteem through the german version (Rudolph et al. 2018) of the questionnaire created by Heatherton & Polivy 1991. There are 15 items with a 5 point scale (1 being "not apply to at all" to 5 "apply to a lot"). Participants should decide how much they apply to these 15 provided sentences. We ask participants to complete the questionnaire before and after their condition and calculate differences in self-esteem.
We will take the mean of all 15 questions above to create a single measure of "self-esteem".

First assumptions for an analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be tested: Normal distribution in each group will be tested with the Shapiro test and the variance homogeneity will be tested with the Levene test.
If the assumptions are met, an analysis of variance (ANOVA) will be performed to investigate if there are differences between the four conditions. Therefore we use a two factor analysis of variance with repeated measures. One factor are the pre/post measures and the other one are the four conditions. If the ANOVA reveals a significant main effect from the conditions (significance level p = 0.05), post-hoc tests will be computed to further examine the specific difference between these four conditions.

In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, where they discussed or solved feelings of jealousy with their romantic partner. Third condition is "situation with ostracism". In this group participants should remember/imagine and write down a situation, where they experienced ostracism in their romantic relationship. If participants did not experience the feeling/event, they should imagine a situation in their current romantic relationship, where they think it is possible to experience this feeling/event.

We ask participants to complete the questionnaire before and after their condition and calculate differences in self-esteem.

attributes.title: Influence of Perceived Deservingness on Welfare Approval

q1.value: The Influence of Perceived Recipient Deservingness on Welfare Approval

q3.value:
This study investigates whether perceptions about welfare recipients changes support for welfare programs. Much economic literature has been devoted to the assumption that individuals’ evaluation of welfare programs is based on calculated self-interest. The Romer/Meltzer/Richard framework argues that support for redistribution grows as median income falls (Meltzer & Richard, 1981). Extensions such as Moene & Wallerstein’s 2003 incorporation of a social insurance explanation also follows the self-interest route. Following these models, the perceived characteristics of other recipients of welfare should make no difference to individuals’ support of such programs. 

Aaroe & Petersen (2014), working from a basis in political science, discuss several other explanations for differences in welfare support among different populations, particularly institutional path dependencies (Larsen, 2007). The thrust of their argument, however, focuses on the micro-level influence of psychology on welfare support. Discussing the concept of a ‘deservingness heuristic’, they emphasize the possibility of a role for “differences in available information”, i.e. media messaging and resulting opinion formation, in changing individuals’ opinion on welfare (Aaroe & Petersen, 2014, p.686).

Aaroe & Petersen (2014) investigate this matter by conducting a cross-national experiment between Danish and American populations, arguing that despite the dissimilar stereotype predispositions of each nationality once individuals are exposed to ‘deservingness cues’ these differences melt away. 

This study intends to conduct a similar experiment among a single population, students at the Stockholm School of Economics,  to see if their core observation is replicable in that environment. 

The experiment consist of one control group, which receives no information as to a hypothetical recipient’s deservingness, and two treatment groups. The first treatment group will receive cues that depict a hypothetical recipient as ‘unlucky’, while the second will receive cues that depict a hypothetical recipient as ‘lazy’. Whether or not these results produce significant differences in individuals’ approval of welfare programs helping these hypothetical recipients would indicate whether individuals’ perceptions of welfare recipients affect their approval for welfare programs.

q4.value:
The primary hypothesis of this paper is that there will be a significant difference in support for welfare programs between experimental groups.

I expect that the first treatment group ('unlucky' recipient cues) will show the highest average support for such programs, the second treatment group ('lazy' recipient cues) the lowest, and the ‘no information’ group somewhere between the two. Pair-wise, this means I expect the mean result from the first treatment group to exceed that of the control group and the second experimental group, and the mean of the control group to exceed that of the second experimental group.

The expected effect size is difficult to quantify, as Aaroe & Petersen (2014) perform their analysis with a regression on the respondents' country of origin and do not report a group or pairwise analysis of the basic experimental conditions' (deservingness cues) effects. Considering the extensive literature supporting deservingness heuristics playing a large role in determining public opinion of welfare (Fong, Bowles & Gintis, 2006, pp. 1439-1461), I expect the true effect size may still be large enough to provide useful results with my sample size.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: The person choosing the respondents who win the random reward will not be aware of the assigned treatments.

question.value:
On a more specific level than in the introduction, I am seeking to evaluate whether simple deservingness cues (or lack thereof) about a hypothetical welfare recipient changes the average response to a question about whether social welfare benefits should continue to go to recipients like the hypothetical person. 

Much of this experiment is focused on replicating and testing a portion of Aaroe & Petersen's 2014 paper "Crowding Out Culture: Scandinavians and Americans Agree on Social Welfare in the Face of Deservingness Cues", published in The Journal of Politics. Aaroe & Petersen's paper focused on cross-cultural differences in stereotypes and the ability of cues to counteract the effects of these stereotypes; this paper differs in that it seeks to replicate the more fundamental question of whether such cues significantly influence respondents' approval of social welfare benefits going to the person. 

This paper further differs from Aaroe & Petersen in methodology: while the two researchers used OLS regressions across national groups, this paper intends to use the Kruskal-Wallis H Test followed by the Mann-Whitney U for pairwise comparisons, should the Kruskal-Wallis find significant or indicative results.

The experiment will be conducted via an online Qualtrics survey, with recruitment occurring through an email to a list of approximately 1700 students current at the Stockholm School of Economics. Prior to answering the experimental question, students will be asked to confirm a standard consent form, be informed of the possibility of winning a 500 SEK prize for participation, and be asked to report their SSE email in the survey itself for verification and prize-drawing.

The experiment itself will contain three treatments:

- Treatment 0 (the control)
- Treatment 1 (the 'unlucky' recipient cue condition)
- Treatment 2 (the 'lazy' recipient cue condition)

Treatment 0, the control group, will be asked a question about approval of social welfare for an individual about whom they are given no deservingness cues, as follows:

"Imagine a person who is on some form of social welfare."

Their response will be selected from a multiple-choice Likert scale, ranging from a value of 1 for Strongly Disagree (that people like the individual should continue to benefit from social welfare) to 7 for Strongly Agree.

Treatment 1, the 'unlucky' group, will be given the following description:

"Imagine a person who is on some form of social welfare. They have worked regularly in the past, but suffered a work-related injury. They have recovered and are very motivated to get back to work."

The response choices will be the same as for question 1.

Treatment 2, the 'lazy' group, will be given the following description:

"Imagine a person who is on some form of social welfare. They are fit and healthy, but have not regularly held a job. They are not motivated to find work."

The response choices will once again be the same.

Students will be randomly assigned one of these three questions through Qualtrics' question randomization option. The survey will be sent out in English and only English on the assumption that students at SSE will have a fluent command of English; SSE's Master's programs are conducted entirely in English and from the fall of 2020 so will its Bachelor's programs. 

The survey will run from the 24th of February to the 28th of March, a period that totals 4 weeks and 5 days. A single follow-up email will be sent out if the response rate is unexpectedly low at the beginning of the final week of the survey period. The e-mail(s) to students will inform them of the payout structure (random draw of 6 email addresses, each receiving 500 SEK unconditionally). Both the email and the survey introduction will attempt to dissuade discussion of the survey until it has run its course. The e-mail(s), survey and survey messages are attached.

q9.value: The survey tool used for this experiment, Qualtrics, has an option that allows for randomization of which questions are presented to an experimental respondent. A respondent will be assigned and only see one of the three treatment questions once they have opened the survey and read & agreed to the instructions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The data for this experiment will be collected through a Qualtrics survey sent out to students' university e-mail accounts at the Stockholm School of Economics. Respondents will be excluded if they do not consent to the experiment on the initial survey landing page, if they do not answer the main survey question, or if they fail to provide a unique SSE student email at the start of the survey. 

The email containing a link to the survey as well as the survey landing page will give a brief overview of the task and inform them that if they complete the survey they will be entered into a random drawing to win 6 allotments of 500 SEK; assuming 300 participants this works out to an expected payment value of 10 SEK per participant. Payment will take place via bank transfer once the experiment has concluded. Eligibility for payment will follow the exclusion criteria above.

The survey will be emailed out to a list of approximately 1700 students on the 24th of February, and run until the 28th of March. During this time the number of respondents will be monitored through Qualtrics to estimate the eventual sample size, but data on responses to the questions will not be visible to the experimenter. 

If at the start of the last week of the survey (on the 21st of March) the number of respondents has not yet reached the target sample size of 300, the experimenter will send out a reminder email.

q13.value: The target sample size for this study is at least 300 respondents. Prior studies using a similar methodology suggests this is an attainable sample size. Due to the randomization method used, this should result in approximately 100 respondents per experimental group. If the response rate is high enough that the sample size is larger this will only increase the strength of the analysis, and will be welcomed.

q14.value:
With the survey sent out to approximately 1750 students, a target sample size of 300 assumes a response rate of approximately 17%; this response rate has proved a reliable target in survey experiments conducted in a similar manner over the past year at SSE.

The target sample size has been set at 300 in order to ideally gather sufficient experimental power to prove or disprove the experimental hypothesis, as otherwise the results would be susceptible to type M or S errors (Gelman & Carlin, 2014).

q15.value: The termination of data collection will occur at the pre-specified ending date of the survey, regardless of how many responses have been collected.

question.value:
The measured variable will be respondents' answers to the survey question, i.e. their support for social welfare in the presence (or absence) of deservingness cues. Operationally, they will choose one of seven options ranging from Strongly Disagree through to Strongly Agree.

Strongly Disagree - 1
Disagree - 2
Somewhat Disagree - 3
Neither agree nor Disagree - 4
Somewhat Agree - 5
Agree - 6
Strongly Agree - 7

The stages of response to the survey question are scaled by a Likert scale as follows:

Strongly Disagree - 1
Disagree - 2
Somewhat Disagree - 3
Neither agree nor Disagree - 4
Somewhat Agree - 5
Agree - 6
Strongly Agree - 7

In order to find means for each group, their answers will be summed via Likert scale value and then divided by the n of each group. This will allow a comparison of the mean of each group in both group and pairwise comparisons.

The hypothesis of this experiment is that there will be a significant difference in the response means for the different experimental groups, i.e. groups that are given different deservingness cues about social welfare will display different levels of approval for social welfare.

The three experimental groups at the Control Group (0), which is given no cues; the 'Unlucky' Group (1), which is given a cue that signals deservingness; and the 'Lazy' Group (2), which is given a cue that signals undeservingness.

Once the means of each group's response has been collected (see Indices section under Variables), a Kruskal-Wallis H Test will be run across all 3 treatment groups. The Kruskal-Wallis H test is a non-parametric extension of the Mann-Whitney U test to more than two groups. Its null hypothesis is that k sampled populations have the same average or median; the alternative hypothesis being that at least one sample is from a distribution with a different average/median. As it is a nonparametric test, it does not require an assumption of a normal distribution in responses from the population, which is something that can’t be assumed with a behavioral response question.

If the Kruskal-Wallis H Test returns a significant (p<0.005) result in rejecting the null hypothesis, each groups' average will be compared with the other groups using pairwise Mann-Whitney U tests. Should the test return an indicative but not a significant result (p<0.05), the Mann-Whitney U tests will proceed with their results considered as suggestive evidence.

q20.value: No transformations of the data should be required beyond the compilation of group averages.

q21.value:
As discussed above, the results of tests will be treated as significant if they are under the p-value threshold of 0.005. If the results show this, it means that the average response to questions differed between groups' different questions.  They will be treated as suggestive evidence if they are under the more traditional p-value threshold of 0.05. Should the results not reach either value, it means that there was no difference in average response to the groups' different questions.

The Kruskal-Wallis H Test & Mann-Whitney U pairwise tests being conducted are two-tailed.

q22.value:
Data points will be excluded on a number of criteria:

To prevent duplicate submissions or participants who are not in the target population, responses will only be included if they also include a valid, unique SSE student email. Should the same email submit multiple responses, all their responses will be excluded, as it is likely they have not seriously answered the question at that juncture.

q23.value: As the survey requires a response to the experimental question, there is no possibility of 'missing' data.

q24.value: There is no exploratory analysis planned for this paper.

attributes.title: Experiences of the Annual Health Check process among men with a learning disability

q2.value:
The study aims to explore the experience of receiving an Annual Health Check (AHC) among men with a learning disability (LD). 

The study will employ an Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis (IPA) design, using face-to-face interviews with 6 to 10 participants in order to explore their experiences of the AHC process – from the initial invitation, through to attending the appointment and the post-appointment stage.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study will follow an IPA methodology. Access to participants will be via Community Learning Disability Teams (CLDT). Purposive sampling will be used to identify potential participants from service users open to the CLDT. Potential participants will be invited to participate in the study by post.

People with a LD will be involved at three principal stages - in the design of the study and the materials used for recruitment and data collection; in the initial analysis; and in a review of the final analysis.

The materials to be used during recruitment and data collection have been co-constructed by the researcher and an Expert Reference Group (ERG) comprised of people with a LD who will not be participants in the study. Study materials have also been reviewed by the CLDT Speech and Language Therapist (SaLT).

Data will be collected using semi-structured face-to-face interviews which will be video recorded. Interviews will be video recorded to capture the use of visual communication aids. Recorded interviews will be transcribed verbatim and include a reference to non-verbal responses and the use of visual aids. Where visual aids have been used to create a graphical representation of participants' experiences a digital picture will be taken to record this. Pictures will not contain identifiable information. Names will be changed and any reference to specific services or locations altered to preserve participant anonymity while retaining the meaning of the containing statement. Once transcribed the recordings will be deleted. 

Whilst it is planned for interviews to be conducted face-to-face in July and August of 2020, If social distancing continues as a result of COVID-19,  then an amended ethics form will be submitted suggesting that interviews are conducted via Skype/video link or alternative web-based video conferencing where participants have access to the technology and the required skills or support to utilise it.

Collected data will be stored securely in order to protect participant confidentiality using the Microsoft OneDrive account registered with the chief investigator and provided by the researchers' University. Transcripts will not be printed. Transcript files will be password protected. Each participant 

Interview transcripts will be analysed according to the principals of IPA and the six stages defined by Smith, Flowers and Larkin (2009) – 1.  reading and re-reading; 2. initial noting; 3. developing emergent themes; 4. searching for connections across emergent themes; 5. repeating stages 1 to 4 for each transcript and 6. searching for patterns between transcripts. To increase reliability a selection of transcripts will be coded by an independent researcher familiar with IPA.

A first draft of the analysis will be shared with an ERG comprised of people with a LD who did not participate in the study and a multidisciplinary team of research supervisors. Both groups will be asked to critique the key themes that the researcher has identified as emerging from the findings.

A final draft of the analysis will be shown to study participants to confirm the accuracy of interpretations of their experience. Participants will be asked during the informed consent stage and the interview debrief if they wish to comment on the accuracy of an accessible summary of the key themes identified as emergent from the findings.

q7.value: Purposive sampling will be employed to create a homogenous group in line with Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis research design.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data collection will proceed in the following stages:

1)	Consent will be reconfirmed at the beginning of the interview using the Participant Information Sheet (PIS) and the informed consent form.

2)	Previous IPA studies have identified that people with a LD may require additional scaffolding (additional questions; written and visual communication aids) during semi-structured interviews. Interviews will be supported by an interview schedule (see attached accessible interview schedule) and visual aids to support participants' understanding and communication. Interviews will be video recorded to capture the use of visual aids. Interviews will last for approximately 1 hour with 30 minutes before to reconfirm consent and address participant questions, and 30 minutes after for participant debriefing.

3)	The interview will take place at either the CLDT base or participants' homes. 

Whilst it is planned for interviews to be conducted face-to-face in July and August of 2020, If social distancing continues as a result of COVID-19,  then an amended ethics form will be submitted suggesting that interviews are conducted via Skype/video link or alternative web-based video conferencing where participants have access to the technology and the required skills or support to utilise it.

4)	Following the interview participants will be debriefed with reference to a debrief letter (see attached accessible debrief letter). The letter has been created in consultation with the ERG, CLDT SaLT and assessed for readability in reference to the Flesch reading ease scale.

q11.value: The study aims to recruit between 6 and 10 participants.

q12.value:
Small sample sizes are the norm within IPA research which aims to understand the individual meaning made of a shared experience of a homogenous group of people. Face-to-face interviews are used to collect in-depth information about each participant's subjective experience. The amount of information collected necessitates that samples are small, typically between 3 and 6. 

A sample size of 6 to 10 has been set for this study in order to take account of the samples' difficulties with communication and to achieve the required depth of information without placing additional stress on individual participants to provide it.

q13.value: Data collection will cease when the upper limit of participants has been reached or data collection exceeds the time set aside for this portion of the study. The study will form part of the researchers' Doctoral qualification in Clinical Psychology. The submission date for the project is April 2020.

question.value: No manipulation of variables is planned.
The study aims to understand the experience of the Annual Health Check process for men with a learning disability.
No statistical analysis will be performed.

q1.value: Einfluss von Eifersucht auf das Kontrollerleben

q2.value: Stefan Comba, Ursina Möckli, Claudia Bühlmann

q3.value: Die Versuchspersonen werden sich in einem Online Experiment an eine Situation erinnern, welche aus 4 Manipulationen anhand des Ausmasses an Eifersuchtsinduktion unterschieden werden kann. Sie werden anschliessend die Situation detailliert niederschreiben. Wir möchten untersuchen, ob sich die Erinnerung an eine der manipulierten Situationen entsprechend auf das Kontrollerleben auswirkt.

q4.value:
Nullhypothese:
«Das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP, unterscheidet sich zwischen 1.) Situation mit Eifersucht, 2.) Situation in der Eifersuchtsgefühle gelöst/besprochen wurden, 3.) Situation mit Ausgrenzung und 4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung) nicht signifikant.» 

Alternativhypothesen:
-	H1a: «Das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in der Bedingung 4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung) ist signifikant höher als das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in Bedingung 1.) Situation mit Eifersucht.»
-	H1b: «Das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in Bedingung 4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung) ist signifikant tiefer als das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in Bedingung 2.) Situation in der Eifersuchtsgefühle gelöst/besprochen wurden.»
-	H1c: «Das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in Bedingung 4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung) ist signifikant höher als in Bedingung 3.) Situation mit Ausgrenzung.»
-	H1d: «Das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben der VP in Bedingung 2.) Situation in der Eifersuchtsgefühle gelöst/besprochen wurden ist signifikant höher als in Bedingung 1.) Situation mit Eifersucht

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Between group Design mit 1 Faktor (Eifersucht) und 4 Stufen 
1.) Situation mit Eifersucht
2.) Situation in der Eifersuchtsgefühle gelöst/besprochen wurden
3.) Situation mit Ausgrenzung 
4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Versuchspersonen werden durch öffentliche Rekrutierung online, Mailinglist der Psychologie an der UZH und via ExPra Teilnehmer angeworben. Der Anreiz besteht in der Möglichkeit für Psychologie-Studierende Versuchspersonenstunden zu sammeln.

Einschlusskriterien sind: 
- Alter > 18J.
- Teilnehmer leben in gegengeschlechtlichen Beziehungen
- Beziehungsdauer von > 6 Monaten
- Unterschriebene Einverständniserklärung

q13.value: Unsere Ziel Sample Grösse würde bei 128 Personen liegen. Begründung siehe Sample Size rationale.

q14.value:
Die Poweranalyse wurde mit GPower durchgeführt.
Bei geschätzter Effektstärke von Eifersucht auf das Kontrollerleben von f = 0.3, Alpha Niveau = 0.05, einer Power von Beta = 0.8 und einer Gruppenanzahl von 4 gelangen wir auf 128 Versuchspersonen.

question.value:
Wir manipulieren die induzierte Eifersucht via Erinnerungs-Situation. Die vier Bedingungen sind:
1.) Situation mit Eifersucht
2.) Situation in der Eifersuchtsgefühle gelöst/besprochen wurden
3.) Situation mit Neid 
4.) letzte positiv erlebte gemeinsame Unternehmung (Kontrollbedingung)

Die gemessene Variable wird das wahrgenommene Kontrollerleben sein, welches wir anhand von 3 9-stufigen Items erheben:
1.) "Ich war frustriert, während ich mich an die Geschichte erinnert habe."
2.) "Ich hatte das Gefühl von Kontrolle, während ich die Geschichte aufgeschrieben habe."
3.) "Ich habe mich ohnmächtig gefühlt, während ich mich an die Geschichte erinnert habe."
(1 = überhaupt nicht, 9 = sehr)

Unterschiede zwischen den Massen den zentralen Tendenz der Gruppen werden mit einer mehrfaktoriellen Varianzanalyse ohne Messwiederholung festgestellt. Die Statistische Analyse wird mit R durchgeführt und das Signifikanzlevel wird auf alpha = 0.05 gesetzt.

attributes.title: Reading text aloud versus highlighting: Comparing their effects on memory and metamemory

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Reading text aloud versus highlighting: Comparing their effects on memory and metamemory

other.value: We will also explore the effects of the amount of text and various characteristics of text read aloud vs. highlighted on all measures.

sample.value: 152 participants recruited via Amazon MTurk online platform.

analyses.value:
A hierarchical Bayesian parameter estimation approach will be used for data analysis based on the 3 (study condition: silent, aloud, highlight) x 2 (study-test lag: immediate, delayed) repeated-measures design, incorporating (1) recognition, (2) confidence, (3) predictions of performance and (4) other metacognitive measures in #1.
The accuracy DV will be modelled as Bernoulli distributed with mean probability predicted via the logistic function by a linear combination of the predictors.
Our initial plan is to model the other DVs as drawn from a censored normal distribution with mean predicted by a linear combination of the predictors and SD estimated from the data (with a uniform prior ranging from observed SD / 100 to observed SD * 10).
For each DV we will construct an ANOVA-like model with deflection parameters for each main effect and their interaction. These deflection parameters will be given gaussian priors with mean 0 and SD estimated from the data. The SDs will be modelled with half-Cauchy priors with scale equal to 5 for logistic models. Each of these deflection parameters will be allowed to vary by participant (for all DVs) and by item (for DVs measured for each item, i.e., accuracy and confidence). These random effects will be modelled as drawn from a normal distribution with mean 0 and SD estimated from the data (with a half-Cauchy prior with scale 5 for logistic analyses and 5 × observed SD for others) and constrained to sum to zero.
Our hypotheses will be examined by estimating the difference between relevant cells on the DV
(proportion correct or mean of the other DVs) and the 95% Highest Density Interval around that estimate. We prefer to consider the estimate and HDI in a quantitative way and not reduce this to binary decisions.
However, we will supplement our primary quantitative evaluation using a region of practical
equivalence (ROPE) approach. The ROPE will be set as a Cohen’s d (with mean estimates above
normalised by the estimated SD in each sample in the posterior) -0.1 to 0.1 for metric DVs. For the binary DV we will set the ROPE as a log odds ratio of +/- 0.1. The ROPE will be used in two ways. First, we will calculate the proportion of the posterior lying above, within, and below the ROPE giving a quantitative estimate in certainty that the true value is within those ranges. Second, we can make a binary decision about the hypothesis by comparing the HDI and ROPE. When the HDI lies completely outside the ROPE, we can conclude a difference with 95% confidence; when the HDI lies entirely within the ROPE we can conclude equivalence with 95% confidence.

Relationships between all measures will be explored using the hierarchical Bayesian parameter
estimation approach.

outliers.value:
Participant exclusion criteria (excluded if they meet one or more of the following): 1) Fail to
comply with encoding instructions (e.g., do not say words aloud or highlight text during re-
reading), 2) Not fluent in English, 3) score at/below chance on two or more of the six texts.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables:
Proportion correct for each text (number correct of out 8).
JOL for each text (0 – 100 on slider scale).
POP (0 – 100 on slider scale)
Effect expectation (0 – 100 on slider scale)
Predictors:
Re-reading condition (silent vs. aloud vs. highlight) – repeated measures (2 texts per
condition)
Recognition (immediate vs. delayed) – repeated measures

conditions.value:
Repeated-measures “one group” design, with an order of the conditions within each block
randomised (but the same for both blocks).

hypothesis.value:
This study will compare the benefits of studying text by reading it silently vs highlighting vs reading it aloud. The six texts from Butler (2010) will be used, each consisting of eight paragraphs. Participants will read the entire article but use a prescribed strategy to study important sections (1/4 to 1/3 of the text), either by reading them aloud (aloud condition), or by highlighting (highlighting condition). In silent condition, the participants will read the entire article silently.  The first three texts will be randomly assigned to the three conditions, and then this order will be repeated for the other three texts (i.e., two blocks). The experiment will be
conducted in two parts with at least 24 hours between the blocks to measure the effect of studying conditions on both immediate and delayed recognition. In the first block, before reading the articles, participants will be asked how often they use each of three study methods (prior experience) and how useful they think these methods are (effect expectation). After studying each text, participants will make a JOL for their learning of that text and asked how familiar they were with the topic of the text (prior knowledge).
In the second block, after studying all three articles, participants will estimate their performance in a multiple-choice test for each article and then answer six blocks of multiple-choice questions (8 questions per text, 1 per paragraph). After each multiple-choice question, they will indicate their confidence in their answer. Following all six tests, they will answer how useful they find each method (change in effect expectation) and how likely they would use each method in the future.
Main Hypotheses
1. Recognition accuracy will be higher in the aloud vs. silent condition (i.e., the production
effect).
2. Recognition accuracy will be higher in the highlighting vs. silent condition (i.e., a highlighting
effect).
3. No prediction is made for whether recognition accuracy will be higher in the aloud vs.
highlighting condition.
4. No prediction is made for whether the effect of aloud vs. highlighting vs. silent
conditions will be different for immediate vs. delayed conditions.
5. Mean JOL will be higher for aloud vs. silent condition.
6. Mean JOL will be higher for highlighting vs. silent condition.
7. No prediction is made for whether JOL will be higher in the aloud vs. highlighting condition.
8. Mean effect expectation will be higher in the second block.
9. Mean prediction of performance will be higher for the multiple-choice questions
corresponded to the articles studied using aloud and highlighting methods vs. silent.
10. No prediction is made for the difference in prediction of performance accuracy for the
multiple-choice questions for highlighted vs. aloud vs. silent studied articles.

Dependent variables:
Proportion correct for each text (number correct of out 8).
JOL for each text (0 – 100 on slider scale).
POP (0 – 100 on slider scale)
Effect expectation (0 – 100 on slider scale)
Predictors:
Re-reading condition (silent vs. aloud vs. highlight) – repeated measures (2 texts per
condition)
Recognition (immediate vs. delayed) – repeated measures
registration_responses.conditions:
Repeated-measures “one group” design, with an order of the conditions within each block
randomised (but the same for both blocks).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This study will compare the benefits of studying text by reading it silently vs highlighting vs reading it aloud. The six texts from Butler (2010) will be used, each consisting of eight paragraphs. Participants will read the entire article but use a prescribed strategy to study important sections (1/4 to 1/3 of the text), either by reading them aloud (aloud condition), or by highlighting (highlighting condition). In silent condition, the participants will read the entire article silently.  The first three texts will be randomly assigned to the three conditions, and then this order will be repeated for the other three texts (i.e., two blocks). The experiment will be
conducted in two parts with at least 24 hours between the blocks to measure the effect of studying conditions on both immediate and delayed recognition. In the first block, before reading the articles, participants will be asked how often they use each of three study methods (prior experience) and how useful they think these methods are (effect expectation). After studying each text, participants will make a JOL for their learning of that text and asked how familiar they were with the topic of the text (prior knowledge).
In the second block, after studying all three articles, participants will estimate their performance in a multiple-choice test for each article and then answer six blocks of multiple-choice questions (8 questions per text, 1 per paragraph). After each multiple-choice question, they will indicate their confidence in their answer. Following all six tests, they will answer how useful they find each method (change in effect expectation) and how likely they would use each method in the future.
Main Hypotheses
1. Recognition accuracy will be higher in the aloud vs. silent condition (i.e., the production
effect).
2. Recognition accuracy will be higher in the highlighting vs. silent condition (i.e., a highlighting
effect).
3. No prediction is made for whether recognition accuracy will be higher in the aloud vs.
highlighting condition.
4. No prediction is made for whether the effect of aloud vs. highlighting vs. silent
conditions will be different for immediate vs. delayed conditions.
5. Mean JOL will be higher for aloud vs. silent condition.
6. Mean JOL will be higher for highlighting vs. silent condition.
7. No prediction is made for whether JOL will be higher in the aloud vs. highlighting condition.
8. Mean effect expectation will be higher in the second block.
9. Mean prediction of performance will be higher for the multiple-choice questions
corresponded to the articles studied using aloud and highlighting methods vs. silent.
10. No prediction is made for the difference in prediction of performance accuracy for the
multiple-choice questions for highlighted vs. aloud vs. silent studied articles.
